questions.text: Which of these tests is used in case of a nominal data?
questions.solution:
Chi-square test deals with nominal/ non-parametric data (qualitative).

Nominal data is one with a name and does not have a numerical value. Ex blood group, gender, religion

Student's t test, ANOVA, and paired t test are used for parametric data (quantitative).

questions.text: Which of the following is true for non-parametric tests?

choices.text: ANOVA is an example of a non parametric test
It is used for skewed distributions
It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution
It cannot be used for small sample sizes

questions.solution:
Non-parametric tests are tests that do not assume that the data is normally distributed. Thus, they are used for skewed (asymmetric) distributions {skewed either to the lesser side (left-sided skewed) or towards the greater side (right-sided skewed)}.

The chi-square test is an example of a non-parametric test that is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

ANOVA is an example of a parametric test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Which of these terms is used for paired t tests?
questions.solution:
Paired t tests are also called correlated pairs t test, paired samples t test, or dependent samples t test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .

questions.text: The test of significance done for two or more proportions:
questions.solution:
Chi-Square(χ2) test is a test used for proportions and associations.

It is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

questions.text: A researcher can use the chi-square test in all of the following situations, except:

choices.text: To test the hypothesis that drug A has the same potency as drug B
To calculate the degree of freedom of a 3 x 4 contingency table
To compare the mean corpuscular volume in normal subjects versus those suffering from hereditary spherocytosis
To compare the proportions of overweight boys and girls in a class

questions.solution:
The Chi-square test is not used for comparing means for different groups as means can only be calculated for quantitative data.

The Chi-square test is used for qualitative data. It can be used:

  • To test the null hypothesis
  • To compare proportions
  • To calculate the degree of freedom

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the Chi-square test?

choices.text: Tests the significance of difference between two proportions
Tells about the presence or absence of an association between two variables
Directly measures the strength of association
It is usually used for skewed data

questions.solution:
A Chi-square test does not directly measure the strength of association. It merely tells about the presence or lack of association.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .

questions.text: A Chi-square test would be most appropriate for testing which of the following hypotheses?

choices.text: The mean AIPGE score of Chennai students is greater than Mumbai students
A smaller proportion of people who were immunized against chicken pox subsequently develop zoster than those who were not immunized
The mean BP of indian, american and english hypertensive men taking ACE inhibitors is the same as that of indian, american and english hypertensive women on ACEIs
The mean cost of treating a patient with CAD by angioplasty is greater than the mean cost of providing medical treatment

questions.solution:
The Chi-square test is used to compare proportions or qualitative variables e.g., whether people developed zoster or not.

Options A and D: Two independent groups are being compared with quantitative variables (exam scores and cost, respectively). Thus, an unpaired t test will be used.

Option C: The blood pressure of 3 groups are being compared, thus making analysis of variance (ANOVA) the most appropriate method of testing significance.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

questions.text: The test of choice to measure the difference in means between two groups in a study, with one group being a control is:
questions.solution:
The test of choice to measure the difference in means between two groups in a study, with one group being a control is unpaired T test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

questions.text: A cardiologist wants to study the effect of the atorvastatin drug. She measures the initial cholesterol levels of 50 patients. After a month's treatment, she measures the cholesterol level again. Which of the following tests will she use to test the statistical significance of the change in the cholesterol level?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the variable (cholesterol level) is quantitative. Moreover, the comparison is being done before and after the treatment (dependent). Hence, a paired t test will be used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

questions.text: In a particular trial, the association of lung cancer with smoking is found to be 40% in one sample and 60% in another. What is the best test to compare the results?
questions.solution:
Chi-square tests are best used in comparing proportions and associations.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

questions.text: A pediatrician carried out a study to assess the difference in growth velocities in boys and girls. The average height of a group of 20 boys aged 10 years was 140 ± 13 cm and for 20 girls of the same age was 135 ± 7 cm. To test the statistical significance of the difference in height, which test would she use?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, two independent groups are being compared with quantitative variables. Thus, a student t test or unpaired t-test is used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .

questions.text: A clinical trial was done between two groups to measure their blood pressure after treatment. Which of the following tests would be appropriate to use?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, two groups are being compared independent of each other. Hence, students t test/ unpaired t test should be used.

T tests are used if 2 groups are being compared. If the same group is compared before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Analysis of variance test is used in which scenario among the following?

choices.text: Comparing proportions in more than 2 groups
Comparing means in more than 2 groups
Comparing means in same groups before and after intervention
Comparing means in less than or equal to 2 groups

questions.solution:
Analysis of variance or ANOVA is used when more than 2 groups are compared for a quantitative difference (means).

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 30 children in rural and 20 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: The standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with a measure of central tendency as mean.

Option D: ANOVA is used to compare more than 2 groups.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A study was conducted to compare the incidence of postpartum depression in mothers as compared to the sex of the child. For assessment, Edinburg Depression scaled score (EDSS) was used. The study was divided into mothers with male babies as one group to be compared with mothers with female babies. Which of the following statistical test will be used to determine the association?
questions.solution:
The Chi-square test is used to compare qualitative data and compares 2 groups with independent measures. The variables used here are yes/no signifying the presence/absence of postpartum depression. Hence it is the most appropriate test here.

Option A: Student’s t-test is for quantitative data. Here the data is qualitative, hence it can't be used.

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: ANOVA is used to compare more than 2 groups.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate test for testing the statistical significance of the difference in heights of school children?
questions.solution:
Analysis of variance or ANOVA is used when more than 2 variable groups are compared.

In the scenario of comparing heights of school children, we would divide the school children into classes or grades or sections or by schools themselves, etc. This would involve comparing more than 2 groups and thus ANOVA is used.

Remember if the question limits its comparison within 2 groups, for example, comparison between boys and girls in a class then we have to choose unpaired t test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: An investigator wants to study the association between maternal intake of iron supplements and the incidence of low birth weight. He collects relevant data from 100 pregnant women regarding the status of usage of iron supplements and the status of birth weight in their newborns. Which of the following tests will he use for his study?
questions.solution:
Here, two qualitative variables are being evaluated. First, whether the child belongs to the low birth weight category or not (and not the actual weight of the child, which is a quantitative value). Second, whether or not the mother took iron supplements in the gestational period. Hence, the chi-square test is used as the test the significance of the association.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: In a study, two groups of newborns are checked for differences in their birth weights based on whether mothers received supplements or not. Which of the following would be most appropriate test of significance?
questions.solution:
The unpaired t-test is used to test the difference between two groups of parametric variables or means when the samples are independent of each other. Here, birth weights (quantitative variable) of the two groups of newborns are being compared, which are independent of each other.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.

  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A study was planned to find out the effect of iron supplementation during pregnancy on the birth weight of newborn children. Two groups, one with iron supplementation and the other without, were compared. Birth weights of newborns were recorded as means + SD. Which statistical test is appropriate for the comparison of birth weights between the two groups?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, we aim to compare only the birth weights of the two groups, which is a quantitative data, and thus an unpaired t test is most appropriate.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: While applying the Chi-square test to a contingency table of 4 rows and 4 columns, what would the degree of freedom be in this case?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, df = (4 – 1) (4 – 1) = 9.

In a Chi-square test for a contingency table, the degrees of freedom (df) = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

 

Related Pearl: Degrees of Freedom

  • In general, degrees of freedom (df) is equal to the number of values minus the numbers of parameters estimated on the way to the obtaining a particular estimate. For example, if we want to estimate the variance between the heights of two people A and B, we would use the values of 2 heights to estimate 1 parameter. Thus, the degrees of freedom in this case would be 2 – 1 = 1.
  • For a Chi-square contingency table, the df = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

questions.text: In a Chi-square test for the following data, the degrees of freedom will be:
questions.solution:
In this scenario,contingency table has 3 rows and 4 columns. Hence, the degree of freedom, df = (3 – 1) (4 – 1) = 6.

In a Chi-square test for a contingency table, the degrees of freedom (df) = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.

Related Pearl: Degrees of Freedom

  • In general, degrees of freedom (df) is equal to the number of values minus the numbers of parameters estimated on the way to the obtaining a particular estimate. For example, if we want to estimate the variance between the heights of two people A and B, we would use the values of 2 heights to estimate 1 parameter. Thus, the degrees of freedom in this case would be 2 – 1 = 1.
  • For a Chi-square contingency table, the df = (r-1) (c-1), where r is the number of rows and c is the number of columns.
